## [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#embassy-executor)embassy-executor
An async/await executor designed for embedded usage.
  * No `alloc`, no heap needed.
  * With nightly Rust, task futures can be fully statically allocated.
  * No “fixed capacity” data structures, executor works with 1 or 1000 tasks without needing config/tuning.
  * Integrated timer queue: sleeping is easy, just do `Timer::after_secs(1).await;`.
  * No busy-loop polling: CPU sleeps when there’s no work to do, using interrupts or `WFE/SEV`.
  * Efficient polling: a wake will only poll the woken task, not all of them.
  * Fair: a task can’t monopolize CPU time even if it’s constantly being woken. All other tasks get a chance to run before a given task gets polled for the second time.
  * Creating multiple executor instances is supported, to run tasks with multiple priority levels. This allows higher-priority tasks to preempt lower-priority tasks.


### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#task-arena)Task arena
When the `nightly` Cargo feature is not enabled, `embassy-executor` allocates tasks out of an arena (a very simple bump allocator).
If the task arena gets full, the program will panic at runtime. To guarantee this doesn’t happen, you must set the size to the sum of sizes of all tasks.
Tasks are allocated from the arena when spawned for the first time. If the task exists, the allocation is not released to the arena, but can be reused to spawn the task again. For multiple-instance tasks (like `#[embassy_executor::task(pool_size = 4)]`), the first spawn will allocate memory for all instances. This is done for performance and to increase predictability (for example, spawning at least 1 instance of every task at boot guarantees an immediate panic if the arena is too small, while allocating instances on-demand could delay the panic to only when the program is under load).
The arena size can be configured in two ways:
  * Via Cargo features: enable a Cargo feature like `task-arena-size-8192`. Only a selection of values is available, see [Task Area Sizes](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#task-arena-size) for reference.
  * Via environment variables at build time: set the variable named `EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE`. For example `EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE=4321 cargo build`. You can also set them in the `[env]` section of `.cargo/config.toml`. Any value can be set, unlike with Cargo features.


Environment variables take precedence over Cargo features. If two Cargo features are enabled for the same setting with different values, compilation fails.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#statically-allocating-tasks)Statically allocating tasks
When using nightly Rust, enable the `nightly` Cargo feature. This will make `embassy-executor` use the `type_alias_impl_trait` feature to allocate all tasks in `static`s. Each task gets its own `static`, with the exact size to hold the task (or multiple instances of it, if using `pool_size`) calculated automatically at compile time. If tasks don’t fit in RAM, this is detected at compile time by the linker. Runtime panics due to running out of memory are not possible.
The configured arena size is ignored, no arena is used at all.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#feature-flags)Feature flags
  * `nightly` — Enable nightly-only features


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#architecture)Architecture
  * `arch-std` — std
  * `arch-cortex-m` — Cortex-M
  * `arch-riscv32` — RISC-V 32
  * `arch-wasm` — WASM
  * `arch-avr` — AVR
  * `arch-spin` — spin (architecture agnostic; never sleeps)


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#executor)Executor
  * `executor-thread` — Enable the thread-mode executor (using WFE/SEV in Cortex-M, WFI in other embedded archs)
  * `executor-interrupt` — Enable the interrupt-mode executor (available in Cortex-M only)
  * `trace` — Enable tracing support (adds some overhead)
  * `rtos-trace` — Enable support for rtos-trace framework


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#timer-item-payload-size)Timer Item Payload Size
Sets the size of the payload for timer items, allowing integrated timer implementors to store additional data in the timer item. The payload field will be aligned to this value as well. If these features are not defined, the timer item will contain no payload field.
  * `timer-item-payload-size-1` — 1 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-2` — 2 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-4` — 4 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-8` — 8 bytes


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#task-arena-size)Task Arena Size
Sets the [task arena](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#task-arena) size. Necessary if you’re not using `nightly`.
Preconfigured Task Arena Sizes:
  * `task-arena-size-64` — 64

    Declares an async task that can be run by `embassy-executor`. The optional `pool_size` parameter can be used to specify how many concurrent tasks can be spawned (default is 1) for the function.

  * Efficient polling: a wake will only poll the woken task, not all of them.
  * Fair: a task can't monopolize CPU time even if it's constantly being woken. All other tasks get a chance to run before a given task gets polled for the second time.
  * Creating multiple executor instances is supported, to run tasks with multiple priority levels. This allows higher-priority tasks to preempt lower-priority tasks.


## Task arena
When the ``nightly`` Cargo feature is not enabled, ``embassy-executor`` allocates tasks out of an arena (a very simple bump allocator).
If the task arena gets full, the program will panic at runtime. To guarantee this doesn't happen, you must set the size to the sum of sizes of all tasks.
Tasks are allocated from the arena when spawned for the first time. If the task exists, the allocation is not released to the arena, but can be reused to spawn the task again. For multiple-instance tasks (like ````#``[``embassy_executor`::`task```(```pool_size `=` 4```)```]````), the first spawn will allocate memory for all instances. This is done for performance and to increase predictability (for example, spawning at least 1 instance of every task at boot guarantees an immediate panic if the arena is too small, while allocating instances on-demand could delay the panic to only when the program is under load).
The arena size can be configured in two ways:
  * Via Cargo features: enable a Cargo feature like ``task-arena-size-8192``. Only a selection of values is available, see [Task Area Sizes](https://lib.rs/crates/embassy-executor#readme-task-arena-size) for reference.
  * Via environment variables at build time: set the variable named ``EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE``. For example ```EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE``=``4321` cargo build``. You can also set them in the ````[``env``]```` section of ``.cargo/config.toml``. Any value can be set, unlike with Cargo features.


Environment variables take precedence over Cargo features. If two Cargo features are enabled for the same setting with different values, compilation fails.
## Statically allocating tasks
When using nightly Rust, enable the ``nightly`` Cargo feature. This will make ``embassy-executor`` use the ``type_alias_impl_trait`` feature to allocate all tasks in ```static```s. Each task gets its own ```static```, with the exact size to hold the task (or multiple instances of it, if using ``pool_size``) calculated automatically at compile time. If tasks don't fit in RAM, this is detected at compile time by the linker. Runtime panics due to running out of memory are not possible.
The configured arena size is ignored, no arena is used at all.

# embassy-executor
An async/await executor designed for embedded usage.
  * No ``alloc``, no heap needed.
  * With nightly Rust, task futures can be fully statically allocated.
  * No "fixed capacity" data structures, executor works with 1 or 1000 tasks without needing config/tuning.
  * Integrated timer queue: sleeping is easy, just do ```Timer`::``after_secs`(``1``)``.`await`;```.
  * No busy-loop polling: CPU sleeps when there's no work to do, using interrupts or ```WFE``/``SEV```.

  * Via environment variables at build time: set the variable named ``EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE``. For example ```EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE``=``4321` cargo build``. You can also set them in the ````[``env``]```` section of ``.cargo/config.toml``. Any value can be set, unlike with Cargo features.

## [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#embassy-executor)embassy-executor
An async/await executor designed for embedded usage.
  * No `alloc`, no heap needed.
  * With nightly Rust, task futures can be fully statically allocated.
  * No “fixed capacity” data structures, executor works with 1 or 1000 tasks without needing config/tuning.
  * Integrated timer queue: sleeping is easy, just do `Timer::after_secs(1).await;`.
  * No busy-loop polling: CPU sleeps when there’s no work to do, using interrupts or `WFE/SEV`.
  * Efficient polling: a wake will only poll the woken task, not all of them.
  * Fair: a task can’t monopolize CPU time even if it’s constantly being woken. All other tasks get a chance to run before a given task gets polled for the second time.
  * Creating multiple executor instances is supported, to run tasks with multiple priority levels. This allows higher-priority tasks to preempt lower-priority tasks.


### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#task-arena)Task arena
When the `nightly` Cargo feature is not enabled, `embassy-executor` allocates tasks out of an arena (a very simple bump allocator).
If the task arena gets full, the program will panic at runtime. To guarantee this doesn’t happen, you must set the size to the sum of sizes of all tasks.
Tasks are allocated from the arena when spawned for the first time. If the task exists, the allocation is not released to the arena, but can be reused to spawn the task again. For multiple-instance tasks (like `#[embassy_executor::task(pool_size = 4)]`), the first spawn will allocate memory for all instances. This is done for performance and to increase predictability (for example, spawning at least 1 instance of every task at boot guarantees an immediate panic if the arena is too small, while allocating instances on-demand could delay the panic to only when the program is under load).
The arena size can be configured in two ways:
  * Via Cargo features: enable a Cargo feature like `task-arena-size-8192`. Only a selection of values is available, see [Task Area Sizes](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#task-arena-size) for reference.
  * Via environment variables at build time: set the variable named `EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE`. For example `EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE=4321 cargo build`. You can also set them in the `[env]` section of `.cargo/config.toml`. Any value can be set, unlike with Cargo features.


Environment variables take precedence over Cargo features. If two Cargo features are enabled for the same setting with different values, compilation fails.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#statically-allocating-tasks)Statically allocating tasks
When using nightly Rust, enable the `nightly` Cargo feature. This will make `embassy-executor` use the `type_alias_impl_trait` feature to allocate all tasks in `static`s. Each task gets its own `static`, with the exact size to hold the task (or multiple instances of it, if using `pool_size`) calculated automatically at compile time. If tasks don’t fit in RAM, this is detected at compile time by the linker. Runtime panics due to running out of memory are not possible.
The configured arena size is ignored, no arena is used at all.
### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#feature-flags)Feature flags
  * `nightly` — Enable nightly-only features


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#architecture)Architecture
  * `arch-std` — std
  * `arch-cortex-m` — Cortex-M
  * `arch-riscv32` — RISC-V 32
  * `arch-wasm` — WASM
  * `arch-avr` — AVR
  * `arch-spin` — spin (architecture agnostic; never sleeps)


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#executor)Executor
  * `executor-thread` — Enable the thread-mode executor (using WFE/SEV in Cortex-M, WFI in other embedded archs)
  * `executor-interrupt` — Enable the interrupt-mode executor (available in Cortex-M only)
  * `trace` — Enable tracing support (adds some overhead)
  * `rtos-trace` — Enable support for rtos-trace framework


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#timer-item-payload-size)Timer Item Payload Size
Sets the size of the payload for timer items, allowing integrated timer implementors to store additional data in the timer item. The payload field will be aligned to this value as well. If these features are not defined, the timer item will contain no payload field.
  * `timer-item-payload-size-1` — 1 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-2` — 2 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-4` — 4 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-8` — 8 bytes


#### [§](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#task-arena-size)Task Arena Size
Sets the [task arena](https://docs.rs/embassy-executor/latest/embassy_executor/#task-arena) size. Necessary if you’re not using `nightly`.
Preconfigured Task Arena Sizes:
  * `task-arena-size-64` — 64
  * `task-arena-size-128` — 128

## §⟨4⟩embassy-executor
An async/await executor designed for embedded usage.
  * No `alloc`, no heap needed.
  * With nightly Rust, task futures can be fully statically allocated.
  * No “fixed capacity” data structures, executor works with 1 or 1000 tasks without needing config/tuning.
  * Integrated timer queue: sleeping is easy, just do `Timer::after_secs(1).await;`.
  * No busy-loop polling: CPU sleeps when there’s no work to do, using interrupts or `WFE/SEV`.
  * Efficient polling: a wake will only poll the woken task, not all of them.
  * Fair: a task can’t monopolize CPU time even if it’s constantly being woken. All other tasks get a chance to run before a given task gets polled for the second time.
  * Creating multiple executor instances is supported, to run tasks with multiple priority levels. This allows higher-priority tasks to preempt lower-priority tasks.


### §⟨5⟩Task arena
When the `nightly` Cargo feature is not enabled, `embassy-executor` allocates tasks out of an arena (a very simple bump allocator).
If the task arena gets full, the program will panic at runtime. To guarantee this doesn’t happen, you must set the size to the sum of sizes of all tasks.
Tasks are allocated from the arena when spawned for the first time. If the task exists, the allocation is not released to the arena, but can be reused to spawn the task again. For multiple-instance tasks (like `#[embassy_executor::task(pool_size = 4)]`), the first spawn will allocate memory for all instances. This is done for performance and to increase predictability (for example, spawning at least 1 instance of every task at boot guarantees an immediate panic if the arena is too small, while allocating instances on-demand could delay the panic to only when the program is under load).
The arena size can be configured in two ways:
  * Via Cargo features: enable a Cargo feature like `task-arena-size-8192`. Only a selection of values is available, see Task Area Sizes⟨6⟩ for reference.
  * Via environment variables at build time: set the variable named `EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE`. For example `EMBASSY_EXECUTOR_TASK_ARENA_SIZE=4321 cargo build`. You can also set them in the `[env]` section of `.cargo/config.toml`. Any value can be set, unlike with Cargo features.


Environment variables take precedence over Cargo features. If two Cargo features are enabled for the same setting with different values, compilation fails.
### §⟨7⟩Statically allocating tasks
When using nightly Rust, enable the `nightly` Cargo feature. This will make `embassy-executor` use the `type_alias_impl_trait` feature to allocate all tasks in `static`s. Each task gets its own `static`, with the exact size to hold the task (or multiple instances of it, if using `pool_size`) calculated automatically at compile time. If tasks don’t fit in RAM, this is detected at compile time by the linker. Runtime panics due to running out of memory are not possible.
The configured arena size is ignored, no arena is used at all.
### §⟨8⟩Feature flags
  * `nightly` — Enable nightly-only features


#### §⟨9⟩Architecture
  * `arch-std` — std
  * `arch-cortex-m` — Cortex-M
  * `arch-riscv32` — RISC-V 32
  * `arch-wasm` — WASM
  * `arch-avr` — AVR
  * `arch-spin` — spin (architecture agnostic; never sleeps)


#### §⟨10⟩Executor
  * `executor-thread` — Enable the thread-mode executor (using WFE/SEV in Cortex-M, WFI in other embedded archs)
  * `executor-interrupt` — Enable the interrupt-mode executor (available in Cortex-M only)
  * `trace` — Enable tracing support (adds some overhead)
  * `rtos-trace` — Enable support for rtos-trace framework


#### §⟨11⟩Timer Item Payload Size
Sets the size of the payload for timer items, allowing integrated timer implementors to store additional data in the timer item. The payload field will be aligned to this value as well. If these features are not defined, the timer item will contain no payload field.
  * `timer-item-payload-size-1` — 1 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-2` — 2 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-4` — 4 bytes
  * `timer-item-payload-size-8` — 8 bytes


#### §⟨6⟩Task Arena Size
Sets the task arena⟨5⟩ size. Necessary if you’re not using `nightly`.

enriched_crate.readme_summary: The `embassy-executor` crate is an async/await executor optimized for embedded systems, requiring no heap or dynamic allocation. It supports efficient task scheduling with integrated timers, fair CPU usage, and low-power operation using interrupts or architecture-specific sleep mechanisms. It offers configurable task allocation via arenas or static memory (with nightly Rust), supports multiple priority-level executors, and is compatible with various architectures like Cortex-M, RISC-V, and WASM.
enriched_crate.factual_counterfactual:
### Pair 1: Task Allocation  
✅ Factual: When the `nightly` Cargo feature is enabled, `embassy-executor` uses the `type_alias_impl_trait` feature to statically allocate tasks in `static`s, ensuring tasks are fully allocated at compile time and eliminating runtime memory panics.  
❌ Counterfactual: When the `nightly` Cargo feature is enabled, `embassy-executor` dynamically allocates tasks at runtime, relying on heap memory to manage task lifetimes.  

---

### Pair 2: Executor Behavior  
✅ Factual: `embassy-executor` ensures fairness by preventing any single task from monopolizing CPU time, allowing other tasks to run before a given task is polled again.  
❌ Counterfactual: `embassy-executor` uses a fixed priority system where higher-priority tasks can indefinitely block lower-priority tasks from being executed.  

---

### Pair 3: Architecture Support  
✅ Factual: `embassy-executor` supports multiple architectures, including Cortex-M, RISC-V 32, WASM, AVR, and spin-based systems, making it suitable for a wide range of embedded applications.  
❌ Counterfactual: `embassy-executor` is limited to Cortex-M architectures and does not support other embedded or general-purpose architectures like RISC-V or WASM.
